awd_titl_txt: SG: Quantifying the contribution of plant-soil feedbacks to coexistence in a sagebrush steppe
awd_abstract_narration:
In many natural ecosystems, dozens of plant species can be found growing together in very small areas. However for over 100 years researchers have struggled to explain why no single species can exclude all the others. It is thought that species can coexist only when the ability of each to outcompete the others is limited by something different. For example, they may each need different resources for growth, be infected by or eaten by different things, or need different environmental conditions. However, showing that this idea holds in nature has proven difficult.  This project will build on existing research on plant coexistence in sagebrush steppes. This research shows that the plant species that are most common coexist because of differences in what limits how successful seedlings are at getting established. These differences in establishment are suspected to be caused by differences in the fungal pathogens living in the soil and infecting roots of the different species. In this study, the researchers will use a field experiment, greenhouse experiment, and computer models based on historical and experimental data to find out how big the role of fungal pathogens is in maintaining the coexistence of plant species. The sagebrush steppe that this work will study is an at-risk ecosystem that has economic and conservation importance. This research will be useful to land managers working in these systems, because it will increase understanding of how important native plant species can be helped in their regeneration. Therefore it will lead to improved ways to manage and restore this ecosystem. The results will be used to create fact sheets for use by land managers, and will be made available to them and to others through existing networks of state, federal, university and NGO personnel interested in sagebrush steppe conservation.

Progress in empirical coexistence research requires integration of modern, quantitative approaches such as population modeling, with classical mechanistic approaches such as experiments targeting specific coexistence mechanisms. This proposal combines these approaches by focusing on one potential mechanism that has recently generated tremendous interest and is likely important in perennial vegetation: plant-soil feedbacks (PSF). First, a field experiment will quantify intra- and interspecific effects of fungal PSFs on germination-emergence and establishment. A companion greenhouse experiment will address questions about differences between field and lab-based PSF studies, and place this case study in the context of the current literature. Second, results from the field experiment will be incorporated in an existing, phenomenological multispecies population model, enabling comparisons of the overall stability of coexistence under a scenario in which only PSFs drive interactions at the recruitment stage, and a scenario including all possible sources of intra- and interspecific effects on recruitment. By combining field experiments, greenhouse studies, long-term demographic data, and models, this work will quantify the contribution of PSFs to the overall stability of coexistence in a sagebrush steppe community. This novel experimental and modeling framework can be extended to other communities and coexistence mechanisms in the future.

por.por_cntn:
When multiple species occur in the same space and compete for similar resources, ecological theory predicts that unless they are limited by different factors, the strongest competitor should overtake all others. Demonstrating this theory in natural field settings has proven difficult, even though we observe more examples of coexistence among species than examples of competitive exclusion. This project built on existing research that showed dominant, coexisting plant species in a sagebrush steppe community were limited by different factors that controlled seedling success. One potential mechanism that has been overlooked could involve interactions between each plant species and specialized belowground fungal pathogens. In a series of field and greenhouse experiments conducted over two years, this project tested whether belowground fungi explained the observed coexistence phenomena.

We found that belowground fungi had strong, consistent, and negative effects on seedling growth for all four plant species investigated. In two growing seasons with different rainfall conditions, seedlings planted in sterilized soils were on average four-fold larger than those exposed to ambient levels of soil microbes. However, while all plant species experienced detrimental effects of soil fungi, these effects were not specific to the fungi harbored by each plant host. For host-specific belowground pathogens to promote coexistence, seedlings should experience the most detrimental effects when exposed to the fungal communities harbored by adults of the same species. We found only a few species pairs for which this was true, whereas on the whole, most fungal effects were not host-specific. Our modeling projections showed that while host-specific fungal pathogens may not play a strong role in the self-limitation of plant hosts, they could have large impacts on their total growth and abundance.

If interactions with belowground pathogens are not helping maintain coexistence in this plant community, what other processes could be? Species could be limited by different aboveground predators or pathogens, by different abiotic resources (water, light, soil nutrients), or by different environmental factors (heat or cold stress). Additional experiments would be needed to evaluate the roles of these mechanisms in promoting diversity.  

In addition to providing a conceptual and experimental framework for future studies that aim to infer coexistence processes from observed patterns, our work also has implications for restoration and the training of early career scientists. The sagebrush steppe ecosystem is foundational to the Intermountain West landscape in the United States, and it is notoriously difficult to restore. Our results suggest that soil fungal pathogens are a potential barrier to establishment for dominant sagebrush steppe plant species, which could be a target to future restoration strategies. This research provided undergraduate research experience to four Utah State University students (two currently employed in related fields), one REU student (current PhD student at Imperial College), and four post-baccalaureate technicians (one now full-time technician at NEON, one current MPH student, one current PhD student). At least one of the trainees self-identifies as a member of a group underrepresented in STEM. The postdoctoral scholar who led this project is now a tenure-track faculty member. The results of our work have been submitted and are under review for publication.
